displayed_text: Family Member: There’s a halo around you that you don’t see, but we do. That’s why we’re here. Doctor: Well thank you. Family Member: Seriously. Family Member: Because you care, that she listens. Doctor: But and I have also have some donor money Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If you know, for medical expenses Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: if it’s getting to be too much let me know, bring it in, and then we’ll consider that. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Alright Family Member: We appreciate you. Thank you for your input.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know that’s an early phase—Phase I study. That clearly has no data as to whether it works. And so you could window it in at this point, but if the scans when we get them show that the stuff that’s in your liver is even big in other areas, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know whether or not you have the willingness or sort of the time to sort of participate in something that’s you know experimental of that nature of a brand new drug is questionable. But some people clearly want to avoid chemotherapy at all costs and are willing to try that even if you know it doesn’t work and they were to miss that opportunity for chemotherapy. So everybody sort of chooses based on who they talk to, who their neighbors are, who’s been through chemo. Doctor: What they are willing to think about. Patient: Yes, I have the time. Yeah. Doctor: Time is one thing, but again you know what the cancer is going to do is the other. Patient: Side effects and all that, yeah, I don’t know what, yeah. Doctor: So those would be potentially three options. If we’re going to go chemotherapy, whether we add in the Vitamin C or not; you get the infusion, you don’t know whether it’s the real thing or Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you get the real chemo. The other one is the immune therapy which my reservation at this point is the gasping thing. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Uh, so as of today, uh, no more Patient: Okay. Doctor: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back. Family Member: She’ll be here tomorrow. Doctor: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose.

Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. They were dealing with somebody that was off, a robber or something. Patient: Okay. Well that didn’t affect our drive. Doctor: No. But I’m sure with the game. Never, never rush. Don’t stress. You know? It’s not great for your sugar and then you’re on the XTANDI. Family Member: You were only fifteen minutes late so it’s fine. Patient: Yeah. And the other issue was this (laugh) Patient: We weren’t aware what we were doing. Family Member: Yeah you were. We had an appointment with this guy Come in at eleven thirty. Right. Doctor: It’s all your fault his sugar is low, not back and forth. (Laughs) Patient: No. He said no (Laughter) Doctor: You feeling better? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.10 years ago or more: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::10 years ago or more

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Homemaker: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Homemaker

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American
What race or races do you consider yours.American Indian or Alaska Native: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::American Indian or Alaska Native

displayed_text: Patient: And then he’ll have the um PSA number at that point in time. Doctor: Yeah and by then we’ll know what trial makes sense um to offer… Patient: You know I do see on the internet, I think it was a… Doctor: Yeah Patient: British article about immunotherapy with prostate cancer… Doctor: Mhmm, Yes. Patient: …and they said they’re starting to see some success. Doctor: Yes. It’s um you know the ones that we have just for prostate doesn’t allow people who’ve had chemo, but we have a couple more in the phase one group that potentially will. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’re gonna tap into those. There’s also um this new trial that’s looking at PSMA that I’m quite interested in. Just a matter of if we have a slot or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It just opened, it just opened. Patient: And what is a PSMA?

Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: - depending on. And then um in point six percent of people you could get a seizure. I point that out out of all the list because that’s to me the most scary - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - if it were me. But you know point six is less – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - than one as in we give this stuff all the time and people, knock on wood - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - have not had it as an issue. Family Member: Everybody has their issues. Doctor: It is. So every time you read that consent form it’s like you opened up a bottle of Motrin, took out the little package insert, (HCP laughing) Family Member: You know even one person Doctor: Um hum. FAM - who’s on the study said oh I had seizures – Healthcare Professional: You have to write it down.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: But I also would prefer the two of you be the voice, you know. ‘Cuz for me to go over it four different times just because -- Family Member: Right. Doctor: Someone’s not able to get here makes it difficult. Family Member: Right. Patient: Well she has court today. Her ex-husband is – Family Member: Being a pain in the ass. Patient: He wants more custody of the kids. So, she has her own mess. Doctor: I get it. Well, what we would be doing is we’d be seeing a lot of you. So, again, some of those visits she – you know, hopefully, the court stuff is better that she can come down with you. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Um. So, does that make sense to try that and go that route? I mean, or is it really you want to think about it more – uh, step back and again talk to your doctor about the chemo again? Do you want to get his opinion or her opinion about the trial? Um. Patient: I think the, the trial’s a little more targeted. The chemo is more general.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are no longer benefiting but the idea is that I want to go to chemotherapy on its own or as part of the study vis a vis switching to this. Patient: How long would the chemotherapy? How long would that last? Doctor: Okay, so the chemotherapy, we tend to give ten cycles if it’s benefiting you. They’re given once every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or if it’s not benefiting you, we usually know by the third or fourth cycle that your PSA is rising and you don’t tolerate it so we have to make some changes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So when the numbers change, it’s consent forms. Patient: Yeah, yeah, put that right Doctor: So that’s your homework. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, and then I will send Dr. G an email tomorrow and make sure he sees what I’m thinking,

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, and is that just a swollen gland from inflammation that’s coming there. Cancer really shouldn’t give you a gland. You know, unless that gland is involved. Um, but that’s where the normal prostate cancer goes. It goes to the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I can’t, I’m not judging. I don’t know what that is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Your CAT scan, uh, says that there’s more, uh, there’s more scarring at the bone sites. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, that’s why they can see scarring on CAT scans, but that’s just again, inflammation. Um. And they love to use . And then, the only change that we see is in your right adrenal gland. Patient: MM, hmm. Doctor: And they’re saying there’s a nodular appearance, and there’s inflammation around it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so, they don’t know what it is. I went up there. That’s why I wasn’t in right when you got here ‘cuz I wanted to go over it with the radiologist. Like, can you tell me what you think it is, and they don’t know. They’re hedging. Okay? Patient: Okay.
